title: Extreme Heat Continues Its March Across Western Europe
abstract: A heat wave that has caused fires to rage in southwestern France and Spain is moving north toward Britain, which may see its highest recorded temperatures ever.

multimedia.caption: At the beach in Brighton, an oasis in southern England.
At the beach in Brighton, an oasis in southern England.
At the beach in Brighton, an oasis in southern England.

title: Prime Minister Race in Britain Remains Unsettled in Wake of Johnson’s Downfall
abstract: Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is the current front-runner, but Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, is making a surprisingly strong run for the leadership position.
byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, has seen her profile rise swiftly in the campaign for prime minister.
Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, has seen her profile rise swiftly in the campaign for prime minister.

title: Ukrainian Plane Carrying Serbian Munitions Bound for Bangladesh Crashes in Greece
abstract: Eight Ukrainian citizens were killed when the cargo plane transporting 11.5 tons of weapons crashed in a field in Greece.
byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Cora Engelbrecht

multimedia.caption: A view of the crash site of an Antonov An-12 cargo plane owned by a Ukrainian company, near Kavala, Greece, on Sunday.
A view of the crash site of an Antonov An-12 cargo plane owned by a Ukrainian company, near Kavala, Greece, on Sunday.
A view of the crash site of an Antonov An-12 cargo plane owned by a Ukrainian company, near Kavala, Greece, on Sunday.

title: As Biden Reaches Out to Mideast Dictators, His Eyes Are on China and Russia
abstract: Looking to make Moscow pay for its Ukraine war, and box China out of Mideast tech deals, the U.S. president tries to fall back on old Gulf alliances.
byline: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: Egypt’s Revolving Jailhouse Door: One Pretrial Detention After Another
abstract: An analysis of handwritten records shows that thousands of Egyptians have been detained without charge, sometimes for years.
byline: By Vivian Yee, Allison McCann and Josh Holder
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
abstract: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.

multimedia.caption: School-aged children last year at an award ceremony in Vladimir, Russia.

title: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
abstract: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.

multimedia.caption: The potential departure of Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, a symbol of European resolve and stability, has unnerved the continent.
The potential departure of Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, a symbol of European resolve and stability, has unnerved the continent.
The potential departure of Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy, a symbol of European resolve and stability, has unnerved the continent.

title: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
abstract: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.

multimedia.caption: Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.
Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.
Travelers on Wednesday at London’s Heathrow Airport. The airport has capped the number of departing passengers until September.

title: Dead but Not Buried, Ex-President’s Body Sparks a Cross-Continental Fight
abstract: José Eduardo dos Santos ruled Angola for 38 years. But he died in Spain. A dispute over where to lay him to rest has divided his family and could decide the fate of his political party.
byline: By Gilberto Neto, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel

multimedia.caption: With his body still in Spain, a portrait was the official focus of mourning in Luanda this week for José Eduardo dos Santos, Angola’s president from 1979 to 2017.
With his body still in Spain, a portrait was the official focus of mourning in Luanda this week for José Eduardo dos Santos, Angola’s president from 1979 to 2017.
With his body still in Spain, a portrait was the official focus of mourning in Luanda this week for José Eduardo dos Santos, Angola’s president from 1979 to 2017.

title: Ex-Goddess Works to Reform 700-Year Tradition. Her M.B.A. Helps.
abstract: As a child, Chanira Bajracharya was worshiped in Nepal, but still made time to study. She is now encouraging the girl goddesses who’ve followed her to do the same.

multimedia.caption: Ms. Bajracharya, then a 12-year-old kumari, in 2007.
Ms. Bajracharya, then a 12-year-old kumari, in 2007.
Ms. Bajracharya, then a 12-year-old kumari, in 2007.

title: A New Palestinian Leader Rises in the West Bank. He’s Very Unpopular.
abstract: Hussein al-Sheikh is considered a possible successor to Mahmoud Abbas, 87, the Palestinian Authority president. But as a liaison to Israel, some critics call him a “spokesman of the occupation.”

multimedia.caption: Hussein al-Sheikh has become the focus of a debate among Palestinians about the vision and legitimacy of their leaders.

title: Crisis in Draghi Government Dismays Italians
abstract: The prime minister’s success in expanding Italy’s influence left many disbelieving that a part of his coalition would knock the country back onto wobbly footing.

multimedia.caption: The Five Star Movement’s senators walked out on a confidence vote over Prime Minister Mario Draghi’s government on Thursday.
The Five Star Movement’s senators walked out on a confidence vote over Prime Minister Mario Draghi’s government on Thursday.

title: The War in Ukraine Is the True Culture War
abstract: With Russia trying to erase Ukraine’s national identity, the fight to preserve, and build upon, Ukraine’s artistic heritage has taken on new urgency.

multimedia.copyright: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
Emile Ducke for The New York Times

title: Mexico’s Leader Says Poverty Is His Priority. But His Policies Hurt the Poor.
abstract: Halfway into the president’s term, the plight of Mexico’s lower classes has only worsened. Economists say it is the result of government mismanagement of welfare programs and the economy.
byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Oscar Lopez

multimedia.caption: Students in a classroom at the Adolfo López Mateos Elementary School, run out of an abandoned train carriage in Naucalpan, Mexico.
multimedia.copyright: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

title: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A heat wave in Europe.

multimedia.caption: Beachgoers in Brighton, southern England, on Sunday. Temperatures in London are forecast to hit 100 or higher on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Reunited in Bucha, a Ukrainian Family Comes to Terms With War’s Traumas
abstract: As flowers bloom amid the wreckage, the Kyiv suburb synonymous with atrocity feels almost normal again. But the lives of the people there may never be.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

title: Your Monday Briefing: In Mideast, Biden Eyes China and Russia
abstract: Also, a heat wave is sweeping across Europe and Egypt is jailing political prisoners.

title: Family Members Mourn a 4-Year-Old Girl Killed in Russian Missile Attack
abstract: The death of Liza Dmytriyeva, a 4-year-old with Down syndrome, encapsulated the brutality of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

title: On Donetsk’s Front Line, Small Gains and Losses Impose a Heavy Toll
abstract: Ukrainian soldiers say they live under almost constant Russian bombardment but dismiss any suggestion that they cede land.
byline: By Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima

multimedia.caption: Ukrainian soldiers taking a break in the minutes after Russian rockets struck a residential area of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine.
Ukrainian soldiers taking a break in the minutes after Russian rockets struck a residential area of Bakhmut, in eastern Ukraine.

title: Britain Girds for Scorching Heat That Could Break Records
abstract: Temperatures may top 100 degrees Fahrenheit in some areas, a rarity that has prompted a national emergency.

multimedia.caption: People sat on the sun-parched grass in Greenwich Park in London on Sunday.
People sat on the sun-parched grass in Greenwich Park in London on Sunday.

title: A Young Woman’s Wartime Task: Persuading People to Leave Their Homes
abstract: In phone calls, doorstep conversations and public speeches, Yana Muravinets has tried to convince people that it’s time to leave villages around the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.

multimedia.caption: Yana Muravinets has helped evacuate more than 2,500 people from the Mykolaiv area while working with the Red Cross, though many people have chosen to stay.
Yana Muravinets has helped evacuate more than 2,500 people from the Mykolaiv area while working with the Red Cross, though many people have chosen to stay.

title: Peeling Paint in Hong Kong Reveals Work of Newly Relevant ‘King’
abstract: When he was alive, the graffiti of Tsang Tsou-choi, or the “King of Kowloon,” was considered peculiar and personal. In a radically changed city, his mostly vanished art now has a political charge.

multimedia.caption: When work by the graffiti artist Tsang Tsou-choi re-emerged beneath a Hong Kong bridge, the mundane setting became an unlikely attraction in a city where dissent has been stamped out.
multimedia.copyright: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times

abstract: College-educated workers are driving a spike in union organizing.

title: Lily Safra, Star-Crossed Socialite and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
abstract: Her life was marked by tragedy, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, but that did not stop her from giving away millions.

abstract: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.

title: Eugenio Scalfari, Leading Italian Journalist, Dies at 98
abstract: As a founder of La Repubblica, one of the country’s major newspapers, and later as a columnist, he left a mark on civic life.

multimedia.caption: Eugenio Scalfari in 1992. He was a founder of the newspaper La Repubblica, a major force in Italian journalism.

title: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
abstract: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger

multimedia.caption: A store hit by shelling in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Saturday. Ukrainian military officials said Ukrainian troops repelled an overnight assault by Russia to capture the main road link between the cities of Lysychansk and Bakhmut.

title: Biden’s Mideast efforts on oil have a precedent: Jimmy Carter’s.
abstract: Jimmy Carter flew to Tehran in 1977 to meet the shah of Iran.

multimedia.caption: President Jimmy Carter toasted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi of Iran during a New Year's Eve dinner at Niavaran Palace in Tehran in 1977.
President Jimmy Carter toasted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi of Iran during a New Year's Eve dinner at Niavaran Palace in Tehran in 1977.

title: Biden Says He Confronted Saudi Prince Over Khashoggi. How True Is That?
abstract: Mr. Biden is by nature a storyteller with a history of relating dramatic tales of conversations with foreign leaders that others in the room do not recall the same way.

multimedia.caption: President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during a summit in Jeddah on Saturday, one day after their encounter.
President Biden and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia during a summit in Jeddah on Saturday, one day after their encounter.

title: Wildfires, and a Heat Wave, Sweep Across Europe
abstract: Fires in the south of France have burned more than 22,000 acres and prompted widespread evacuations. Britain was bracing for record high temperatures early next week.
byline: By Aurelien Breeden and Isabella Kwai

multimedia.caption: A restaurant destroyed by flames on Friday near La Teste-de-Buch, in southwestern France.
A restaurant destroyed by flames on Friday near La Teste-de-Buch, in southwestern France.

title: Salad Days
abstract: When it comes to making the perfect summer salad, sometimes less is more.

title: An unspoken result of Biden’s meeting with Prince Mohammed: A setback in the Khashoggi case.
abstract: President Biden’s dropping of his resistance to speak with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seems to signal the end of official U.S. efforts to seek justice for the slain journalist.

multimedia.caption: Saudi officials eventually acknowledged Jamal Khashoggi’s murder, but insisted that it had been carried out by rogue agents with no orders from Riyadh.

title: Turbulence on the Ground at Toronto’s Pearson Airport
abstract: Airports around the world are struggling to keep pace with the summer travel boom.
